Name: Dithiopyr
Description: Dithiopyr is a member of pyridines, a thioester and an organofluorine compound.

plant_translocations.content: A greenhouse study was conducted to determine the effectiveness of adjuvants on postemergence large crabgrass control with dithiopyr. Using barriers to isolate foliage or soil, the primary site of dithiopyr uptake was found to be via foliage. Laboratory and greenhouse studies elucidated the factors involved in enhancement of crabgrass control by dithiopyr with nine superior adjuvants. Two adjuvants increased dithiopyr absorption by 3.7 to 4.3% over the herbicide alone. However, none of the adjuvants increased dithiopyr translocation out of the treated leaf. Treatment of a single large crabgrass leaf indicated that enhancement of dithiopyr activity by adjuvants involved an effect on translocation, on spray retention, and on the external movement of the spray solution to the apical meristem, with the relative importance of any 1 factor depending on the particular adjuvant used. Because of the large losses of dithiopyr during absorption/translocation studies, a separate volatilization experiment determined that 70% of the applied dithiopyr volatilized within 24 h at 24 C. Dithiopyr absorption decreased and volatilization increased with each 10 C increase in temperature. Nonrecoverable dithiopyr ranged from 46 to 55% at 5 C to 92 to 95% at 35 C. Volatility losses of this magnitude may mitigate adjuvant enhancement of postemergence grass activity of dithiopyr.
plant_translocations.reference: Keeley, S. J., Branham, B. E., & Penner, D. (1997). Adjuvant enhancement of large crabgrass (Digitaria sanguinalis) control with dithiopyr. Weed science, 45(2), 205-211.

method.Apply Location: The experiments involved both foliar and soil applications of the herbicide dithiopyr.
method.Plant Grown Condition: Large crabgrass was grown from seed in 355-ml styrofoam cups for the greenhouse experiments. For the absorption/translocation study, plants were grown in Baccto potting media.
method.Chemical Preparation: the treatment solution contained 12.1 μg dithiopyr, 425 Bq of 14C-labeled dithiopyr (specific activity 1.08 x 103 MBq/mmol, uniformly ring-labeled), and adjuvants at 0.5% v/v in a final volume of 10 μL.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: The dithiopyr rates evaluated in the site of uptake experiment were 10, 20, 40, and 70 g ai/ha. In the absorption/translocation study, the treatment solution was equivalent to a dithiopyr spray solution containing 280 g ai/ha at a spray volume of 234 L/ha.
method.Other Information: The site of uptake experiment used a two-factor randomized complete block design with six replications.

plant_translocations.content: Nutrient culture study was initiated to examine the selectivity of dithiopyr (S, S-dimethyl 2-difluor.omethyl)-4-(2-methylpropyl)-6-(trifuoro methyl)-3, $-pyridine dicarbothiate) in rice (Oryza sativa L.) and barnyardgrass (Echinochloa crusgalli Beauv.). Absorption and translocation of dithiopyr in rice and barnyardgrass were also investigated to determine their selective mechanism. Rice was very tolerant, but barnyardgrass was susceptible to dithiopyr. The absorption of dithiopyr was greater in barnyardgrass than in rice and most of them remained in the roots of both species. Dithiopyr was absorbed by roots and basal shoots of both species. Translocation of dithiopyr was very low but was higher in barnyardgrass than in rice. Therefore, this study suggests that the selectivity of dithiopyr between rice and barnyardgrass may be mainly attributed to the absorption and translocation of dithiopyr in plants.
plant_translocations.reference: Pyon, J. Y., Kang, K. S., & Ryang, H. S. (1994). Absorption and translocation of dithiopyr and its mechanism of selectivity in rice and barnyardgrass. Korean Journal of Weed Science, 14(1), 23-27.

method.Test Plant: Rice cultivar Chuchung (Oryza sativa L. cv. Chuchung) and barnyardgrass
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seedlings of rice and barnyardgrass were grown in Kasugai nutrient solution until the 2 and 4 leaf stages in a growth chamber set at 25/20°C (day/night).
method.Chemical Preparation: For the selectivity study, dithiopyr was applied at rates of 10^-8, 5x10^-8, 10^-7, 5x10^-7, and 10^-6 M. For the absorption and translocation study, 14C-dithiopyr supplied by Monsanto Company was used, which was pyridine ring-labeled with a specific activity of 72.5 μCi/mg. A concentration of 5x10^-8 M 14C-dithiopyr was used for the absorption and translocation experiments.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: For the selectivity study, roots of rice and barnyardgrass seedlings were treated with dithiopyr solutions for 10 days, then transferred to Kasugai nutrient solution and grown for 4 more days. For the absorption and translocation study, roots or roots+3cm basal shoots of 2 leaf stage seedlings were exposed to 500 ml of 5x10^-8 M 14C-dithiopyr for 6, 12, 24, and 48 hours.
method.Other Information: In the selectivity study, dry weights of roots and shoots were measured after plant harvest.
